criteria: Application of Knowledge to Real-World Scenarios
descriptions: The student does not identify any risk factors for injuries.
The student identifies one or two risk factors, but lacks detail or clarity.
The student identifies some risk factors in one setting (home, school, or community) with basic explanations.
The student identifies several risk factors across multiple settings, providing adequate explanations.
The student comprehensively identifies a wide range of risk factors across all three settings with clear and detailed explanations.
The student expertly identifies and explains an extensive range of risk factors across all settings, demonstrating a deep understanding of potential hazards.
The student does not propose any strategies for reducing injury risks.
The student proposes one or two vague or impractical strategies.
The student proposes some basic strategies for risk reduction in one setting.
The student proposes relevant and feasible strategies across multiple settings.
The student proposes well-developed and practical strategies that address multiple risks in all three settings.
The student proposes innovative, comprehensive, and highly effective strategies that demonstrate a thorough understanding of risk reduction principles in all settings.
The student fails to apply knowledge of risk reduction to real-world scenarios.
The student struggles to apply knowledge to specific scenarios; application is unclear or inaccurate.
The student applies knowledge to one or two simple scenarios with limited detail.
The student effectively applies knowledge to several realistic scenarios, showing a good understanding.
The student skillfully applies knowledge to a variety of complex, real-world scenarios with detailed explanations.
The student masterfully applies knowledge to diverse and challenging scenarios, demonstrating insightful understanding and nuanced problem-solving.
